title.narrative: Enhanced safety of crisis-affected civilians in Iraq from threats of explosive remnants of war (ERW) and improvised explosive devices (IEDs)

description.narrative:
Due to decades of war and the conflict against the Islamic State (IS) Iraq is known to be one of the most contaminated countries in the world in terms of ERW and IEDs putting high number of population at risk of permanent injuries and death. While the extent of the contamination remains largely unknown, the impact on civilians will be extensive if people return before areas are cleared. IEDs have been used extensively by IS in urban prior to their departure secreted within schools, health centres, public and residential buildings, as well as along the main routes and roads. The exact number of casualties of CW and IEDs in Iraq remains unknown but the civil population is often the first victims. One of the main causes of disability in Iraq is caused by accidents due to ERW and IEDs. According to Action on Armed Violence (AOAV), a founding member of the International Network on Explosive Weapons (INEW), between 2011 and 2015, 82% of people killed or injured by CW and IEDs in Iraq were civilians. By June 2016, AOAV had recorded a total of 36,772 casualties from IEDs in the country. For instance, a recent document released by iMMAP about the explosive incidents in Mosul highlights that 262 hazard incidents were recorded between 17th October and 30th November 2016, out of which 220 were IED incidents, 10 landmine incidents and 3 ERW incidents.
General objective: This project aims to promote peace and stability by protecting lives of IDPs, local population and returnees from the risks of ERW and IEDs in Ninewa and Anbar.
Specific objectives:
1. To enhance the safety and security of the civilian population by reducing the immediate threat posed by ERW and IEDs through provision of risk education to IDPs, returnees and local populations
2. To empower communities to manage the risk caused by ERW and IEDs through the identification and training of Community–based Risk Education (CBRE) volunteers and Youth Ambassadors who are aware of the risks from ERW/IEDs and are able to develop/plan/prioritise for risk mitigation responses.
